title: Indigenous Peoples of São Vicente, Brazil (Pindorama)
header: Indigenous Peoples of São Vicente, Brazil (Pindorama)

maps.text: Different regions were defined in past centuries by non-native people.

common.text: Reflection 1: About genealogical trees

### The Peopling of Brazil

It is not unusual to talk with people and, when asking them *"Who discovered Brazil?"*, to receive the answer: *"The Portuguese"*. But how could the Portuguese have *"discovered"* it when there were already people here?

Another important issue is the traditional approach to history teaching, which frequently omits the existence of *Pindorama* (the Indigenous name for the Brazilian territory) (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). The conventional narrative only begins discussing this region when it becomes "Brazil".

This text seeks to recover the memory of Indigenous peoples by presenting their familial and social structures. We will also discuss racial mixing and attempt to reassess their Indigenous past (<htcite2>).

#### The First Inhabitants

**Figure 1** shows a map with territorial borders established over centuries, which differ significantly from the lands occupied by hunter-gatherer peoples. These groups moved seasonally, adapting to climate changes (<htcite0>).

The first inhabitants arrived around <htdate0> and remained in the region until <htdate1>. They did not practice agriculture nor use ceramics, living mainly along the coast, where they had abundant marine protein sources. The accumulation of shells and bones formed **sambaquis** (shell mounds) (<htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>).

Another key detail is their life expectancy, estimated at around 30 years (<htcite4>), which contrasts with European accounts from the early colonial period.

Although they declined with the arrival of the Tupi-Guaraní, there is no evidence they went completely extinct; instead, they integrated with the newcomers (<htcite5>). Some researchers suggest the *Botocudos* may be their descendants (<htcite6>).

#### Tupi-Guarani

By <htdate0>, the Tupi-Guaraní—originating from the continent's interior—reached the coast, displacing earlier groups. Unlike their predecessors, they had ceramics, agriculture, and warfare techniques, using bows and arrows (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

In the 500 years before colonization, these groups were mainly coastal. The Tupi, however, preferred the highlands, where the land was better for farming, only visiting the coast for fishing and rituals (<htcite2>).

It is also important to note the internal conflicts and territorial divisions that emerged with the Tupi-Guaraní migration. An emblematic example is the warfare between the Tupi and Carijós (<htcite3>).

#### The Arrival of Europeans

The European colonization of South America (known as *Abya Yala* by Indigenous peoples) brought profound changes, including a demographic collapse that reduced Indigenous populations by millions (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Additionally, the Treaty of Tordesillas (**Figura 2**) (<htcite2>) wimposed territorial divisions without Indigenous consent.

Figure 2: Page from the Tratado de Tordesillas mentioning Rui Leme (Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal - BNP, BN MS. 5, n.º 25, F. 6r). ).

Reflection 2: On Land Division

Imagine a scenario where a group of people gathers for a meeting and decides to divide the world among themselves, claiming ownership of everything that has been built over millennia. Would you feel comfortable with the idea of being left with nothing?

We also highlight an aspect in **Figure 1**, based on Dr. Jorge Pimentel Cintra’s research. His analysis of Luiz Teixeira’s <htdate0> map—depicting the hereditary captaincies divided horizontally—cross-references land grants and records from the Torre do Tombo. Using this framework, Dr. Cintra proposes a revised map of the captaincies. In this text, we focus specifically on São Vicente and Santo Amaro (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

prerequisites: Indígenas de Abya Yala (América): Una visión general de cómo ocurrió la migración hasta América.

history.text:
It is impossible to determine individual names when working with sambaquis. Therefore, denying their existence would be much worse. With this, we will present some individuals as "unknown".

Their presence in the Brazilian territory (*Pindorama*) is incontestable, with sambaquis found in different regions (<htcite0>). The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) collected in Thiago Ferraz da Silva’s research shows that individuals had haplogroups characteristic of the Americas (*Abya Yala*)—A2, B2, C1b, C1c, C1d, and D1—with a rare exception: C4c (<htcite1>).

As for the Y chromosome, the identified haplogroup was Q1b, the most common among Indigenous peoples of South America (*Abya Yala*) (<htcite2>).
The details about this millennia-old individual were presented earlier in this text. We selected mtDNA A2 as an example.
Like their supposed spouse, we are not providing more details beyond what has been stated.
Given the size of the sambaquis and the archaeological data collected, there is no doubt they had children.

As a Brazilian Indigenous woman, few records about her can be found from the 16th century, according to the Gregorian calendar.

We begin the family line with her, respecting the Indigenous matriarchal traditions discussed in the text about the Indigenous peoples of *Abya Yala* (<htcite0>).

She lived in the 16th century, during a historical period marked by the arrival of Europeans on the Brazilian coast, around the year <htdate0>, as shown in her daughter’s testimony during the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>).

Her Indigenous origin has been known for centuries, noted in the marriage dispensation of her descendants, Brás Esteves and Maria de Luiz Cunha, in the year <htdate1>, and corroborated by recent genetic testing (<htcite1>; <htcite2>). Nevertheless, we have no indication of how she was known among her Indigenous parents and relatives, and only have the name she received after colonization began.

Without providing any documentation to support his claim, Luiz Gonsaga da Silva Leme referred to her as “Portuguese”. However, that is not the only notable point in his text. When discussing her husband and the couple’s possessions in the 16th century, he mentions part of the São Jorge dos Erasmos sugar mill which, despite the unclear date of its founding, was already facing problems in <htdate2>, as shown in a document preserved in the *Archives Généraux du Royaume* in Brussels, Belgium (<htcite3>; <htcite4>; <htcite5>).
She was mentioned by her daughter in testimony during the process for Saint José de Anchieta
According to her own daughter

Various authors have recorded different spellings of her name. In this text, we adopt the version found in the marriage dispensation of her descendants (<htcite0>).

As with her mother, there is little direct information available about her. The most notable detail is her longevity, mentioned in her testimony during the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta, in which, in <htdate0>, she declared herself to be over 80 years old (<htcite1>).

She died in <htdate1>, having had seven children (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).
As recorded in her inventory and that of her husband
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory, through her husband, and indirectly through her own inventory
According to the mother's inventory
According to the mother's inventory

Izabel do Prado had a long life, like her mother, passing away in <htdate0>. After the death of her husband, Pascoal Leite, in <htdate1>, she did not remarry (<htcite0>).

A mistaken publication by Pedro Taques de Almeida Paes Leme attempted to link her husband, Pascoal Leite, to Pascoal Leite Furtado, and several researchers and historians repeated this incorrect information. However, the publication of probate records (inventory), the *De Genere* by João Leite da Silva, and the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta helped correct the error (<htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>; <htcite4>).

Izabel do Prado’s probate record (inventory) only mentions male heirs. Therefore, we recommend consulting the work of José Guimarães for a more detailed study of the lineage. For now, we focus solely on Maria Leite, who married Pero Dias (<htcite5>; <htcite6>).
Mentioned in the *De Genere* of her grandson, as well as appearing in her father-in-law’s probate record
According to the *De Genere* of her son (<htcite0>).

Her generation (<htcite0>) is mentioned within her husband’s family. In this text, we only highlight that she was the mother of a *bandeirante* who, despite having Indigenous mtDNA, took actions against his own relatives (<htcite1>; <htcite2>).

source.text: de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P.
Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., Vol. III

history.text: Mentioned in her son's *De Genere* and in her inventory

Helena do Prado is mentioned in her mother’s inventory as the wife of Pero Leme (<htcite0>).

Details about her children are available on her husband's page.

When her son, Domingos Leme da Silva, married on <htdate0>, both she and her husband had already passed away (<htcite1>).
Mentioned in her mother's inventory

Felippa Vicente appears with a spelling different from that of her mother, as noted in the transcription of her inventory (<htcite0>).

Her family connection is evidenced by the mention of her husband, Luiz Furtado, who appears:
- In her own inventory (<htcite1>).
- In her mother’s inventory (<htcite2>).

Her inventory helps correct an error made by Luiz Gonzaga Silva Leme, which was later identified by Américo de Moura in <htdate0> (<htcite3>). The following can be observed:
- Luiz G. Silva Leme suggested that João de Prado (Felippa’s grandfather) arrived in Brazil around <htdate1>, although documentation only places him in the <htdate2>s, according to the Gregorian calendar (<htcite4>; <htcite5>).
- Relevant demographic data: Felippa’s eldest son was 14 years and the youngest daughter was only 1 year old when she died (<htdate3>) (<htcite6>). Her mother declared that she was over 80 years old in <htdate4> (<htcite7>), making it unlikely that she had married João de Prado during the early years of colonization.

This evidence supports the hypothesis by Américo de Moura that her mother's marriage to João de Prado occurred around <htdate5> (<htcite8>), when she would have been approximately 28 years old.
Mentioned in her husband's inventory

João do Prado, the son bearing the same name, passed away in <htdate0>, leaving behind three children. The eldest, João, was five years old, and the youngest, Domingos, was only one (<htcite0>). This information, along with that of his sister Felippa Vicente, provides additional evidence that helps support the hypothesis proposed by Américo de Moura (<htcite1>; <htcite2>).
Mentioned in her husband's inventory

#### Villages

Indigenous peoples had their own social organizations before the arrival of the colonizers in Brazil (*Pindorama*). These organizations were not necessarily fixed and are known as *"villages"* (<htcite0>).

With colonization, the villages began to be referred to as settlements, and through a <htdate0>, law, they became *"Royal Patron Villages"* (<htcite1>). This law established, among other points, that the settlements should be "*situated at a sufficiently safe distance from white population centers*" (<htcite2>).

#### Carapicuíba

In this section, we focus our study on the *"Jesuit Village of Carapicuíba"* (<htcite3>).

The exact date of this village’s founding is uncertain. Some claim it was founded by Saint José de Anchieta, but no known documents exist to support this claim (<htcite4>). Given this, the safest position is to accept that the *"Jesuit Village of Carapicuíba"* was founded in <htdate1>, on lands donated by Afonso Sardinha (<htcite5>; <htcite6>).

source.text: Barcala, V. A., & Barcala, J. C.
Barcala, V. A., & Barcala, J. C.
Barcala, V. A., & Barcala, J. C.

history.text: When reading Luiz Gonzaga Silva Leme, we observe that he mentions an *"aldêa Carapucuiba"* (<htcite0>). When we searched for documents about a village with this spelling, we found no results, leading us to suppose it was a typographical error, and that the intention was to refer to the village of *Carapicuíba*.

No document proves the existence of this person, their father, or their marriage. However, for some reason, in the 20th century, according to Gregorian calendar, these figures are mentioned (<htcite0>).

In the early, according to Gregorian calendar, she was cited in a supposed marriage (<htcite0>), which did not occur, as shown by contemporary testimonies from those involved in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite1>):

- Mateus Luiz Grou, her supposed son, stated he was the son of *"Domingos Luiz Grou and Maria da Peña"* (<htcite2>).
- Álvaro Neto, in his testimony, stated that Domingos Luiz Grou was *"his brother-in-law"* (<htcite3>).
- Mência da Peña, wife of Álvaro Neto, stated that her parents were *"Antonio da Peña e Francisca de Góes"* (<htcite4>)".

With this evidence, the lineage proposed centuries later becomes unsustainable, leading to doubts about the existence of these Indigenous individuals.
Mentioned in a 20th-century narrative (<htcite0>), according to Gregorian Calendar.

#### The people

The Carijós were one of the three Indigenous peoples (Carijós, Tupiniquins, and Tupinambás) who inhabited the territory of present-day São Paulo before the arrival of the colonizers. However, they did not live exclusively in this region: their territory extended across what is now southern Brazil (*Pindorama*) and reached present-day Paraguay (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

The absence of a writing system among the Carijós makes it impossible to carry out an accurate account of this people. Furthermore, according to Father Jácome Monteiro, they were a *"more domestic and political"* people (<htcite2>). For this reason, they ended up being victims of the paulistas, who took around **120,000** to "serve the settlers or to be sold" (<htcite3>).

#### Social organization

Regarding their social organization, Pedro Ignácio Schmitz and Jairo Henrique Rogge transcribe excerpts from the work of S. Leite that note, among other things:
- the existence of *"sorcerers"* as a third type of leadership;
- a division into *"two idolatrous lords,"*, referred to by S. Leite as *"Angel"* and *"Great Parrot"*.
- the *"sorcerers"*, called *Caraibebe*, had no more than one wife — something unusual among the Carijós.

#### Family

The concept of family among the Carijós followed the pattern described by Morgan for the Indigenous peoples of the northern part of the American continent (*Abya Yala*). These were consanguineous families, with no restrictions on relationships between close generations (<htcite4>). The lack of understanding of this type of family structure led Jesuit priests to interpret it prejudicially, crudely labeling the Carijós as *"extremely dirty"* (<htcite5>).

#### On the priests’ descriptions

As Pedro Ignácio Schmitz and Jairo Henrique Rogge point out, the descriptions provided by the priests do not constitute detailed studies and should be interpreted with caution, given that ethnography emerged only centuries later (<htcite6>).

source.text: Schmitz, P. I., & Rogge, J. H.
Schmitz, P. I., & Rogge, J. H.
Schmitz, P. I., & Rogge, J. H.
Schmitz, P. I., & Rogge, J. H.
Schmitz, P. I., & Rogge, J. H.

history.text:
#### Disguised Slavery

When analyzing **Volume 7 do Registro Geral da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo**, covering the years 1594 to 1724, we find records of Carijó Indigenous people delivered as *"fôrros"* to different colonizers (<htcite0>). However, as João Lúcio Azevedo points out, what actually took place was far more lamentable (<htcite1>):

source.text: Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo

history.text: • "The Indigenous people, brought down through simple persuasion, or rather by the deceit of petty gifts, were considered freedmen and, in this condition, had the right to wages; but in fact, they lived as enslaved as the others."
Book 1: Registro Geral de São Paulo, Volume VII.

#### The Carijó Family

Because the Carijó had a distinct family organization (<htcite0>; <htcite1>)—which does not mean “unclean”—we will not treat them as we did other Indigenous groups mentioned earlier, who had already been “influenced” by colonizers.

Instead, we will list the individuals identified in the General Registry of the São Paulo City Council as belonging to the Carijó family, indicating the pages on which they appear (<htcite2>) and omitting the names of the colonizers who “received” them. We have also included some Black people exploited by the colonizers, for they were as human as any other enslaved person:

source.text: Schmitz, P. I., & Rogge, J. H.
Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo

- **132**: Guaraguissá, Guarahai, 3 boys. Guaraobi, ..., five boys. Maracaiú, ..., a boy. J..by, .., niño. Pirahuhu, .... Caraoatá, and her mother. Atabú. ..., ..., a boy.
- **133**: Antonio, Marina, Amador. Barbara, Potencia, Ursula. Paulo, Clara, two children. Estevão, ..., Luiza. Fernando, Antonia. José, Marquesza, a boy.

Before proceeding, we note a few points: in the first part of the list there is mention of Black people, of infants, and omission of the names of several women. In addition, elders are referred to pejoratively as “old.”

Continuing (<htcite0>):

source.text: Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo

source.text: Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo

history.text:
#### The End

When studying the records of São Paulo, we see that mentions of Black people among the Carijó Indigenous in <htdate0> (<htcite0>) were very few. Over the years, the situation reversed: there were few Indigenous people mentioned in Minas Gerais, and the price of an Indigenous person was lower than that of an enslaved African, since the former were considered “less productive” (<htcite1>).

The Carijó were not completely exterminated by the colonizers, but over time they were marginalized and lost their identity entirely, as reported by Renato Pinto Venâncio (<htcite2>).

source.text: Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo

exercise_v2.question: Were there inhabitants in Brazil (Pindorama) before the invention of writing in Sumer, that is, more than 6 millennia ago?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The dating of the first written Sumerian records goes back about 5,400 years, while the creators of sambaquis lived in Brazil approximately 10,000 years ago. Therefore, there were people in Brazilian territory long before the emergence of writing in Sumer.

exercise_v2.question: Have Indigenous peoples always been referred to as Indigenous by 20th-century writers?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Later texts mistakenly refer to Indigenous people as if they were Europeans, or attribute to Europeans marriages with Indigenous people when, in fact, their wives were European.

exercise_v2.question: Did colonizers show respect and have an accurate understanding of Indigenous cultures?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Various texts produced by Jesuits show that there was no full understanding of Indigenous cultures, which is evident in the inaccurate descriptions made about these peoples. They were definitely not scientists studying Indigenous societies. Furthermore, a colonizer generally seeks to exploit — not improve — the lives of the colonized.
